title: I'm A Functional Medicine Doctor & Here Are The 10 Teas I Drink During Flu Season
description: Tea is packed with nutrients, each variety (white, green, black, oolong, and herbal) boasting its own benefits. Here are the best ones for cold & flu season.
cleaned_text: 10 Immune-System-Boosting Teas, According To A Functional Medicine Doc [By William Cole, IFMCP, DNM, D.C.](/wc/william-cole-dc) Tea is packed with nutrients, each variety ( [white, green, black, oolong, and herbal](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/health-benefits-of-drinking-tea-and-the-different-types)) boasting its own unique set of benefits. And while I like to drink all types, there are certain varieties I gravitate toward depending on the benefits I am looking to tap into. When I feel a cold coming on, I reach for the varieties I know will build up my immune system to fight off illness completely or at least reduce my symptoms. Here are the top 10 I like to curl up with during cold and flu season: Advertisement 1. Elderberry Elderberry is so powerful that even Hippocrates, the father of modern medicine, praised its healing abilities, referring to it as his "medicine chest." Its [antimicrobial and antiviral properties](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3056848/) [1](#citations) have been borne out in many studies, and it has been shown to be a viable remedy against both pathogenic bacteria and influenza viruses. In addition to being steeped in tea, [elderberry can be found as a syrup](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/elderberry-syrup-benefits-recipes-and-why-you-should-take-it) and is a common ingredient in cold and flu medicines. 2. Echinacea This herb is also known for its antiviral and antibacterial properties. You might even recognize echinacea as a common ingredient from your pharmacy's cold and flu aisle. I prefer to take echinacea in tea form, so I can sip it throughout the day. Pro tip: Increasing the steep time will increase its dosage and potency. Advertisement 3. Hibiscus This herbal tea is a great choice when you are feeling under the weather, due to its vitamin C content. Studies have shown that [vitamin C can reduce cold symptoms](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1940935/) [2](#citations) by up to 30%. 4. Ginger For digestive distress, [ginger reigns supreme](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/health-benefits-of-ginger-x-uses-for-ginger-root-tea-and-extract). Ginger eases nausea and soothes an inflamed gut. In fact, studies [have shown](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4818021/) [3](#citations) it is so powerful that it can help ease the nausea associated with pregnancy and chemotherapy side effects. Advertisement 5. Slippery elm [Slippery elm](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/slippery-elm-benefits-side-effects-and-exactly-how-to-use-it-for-constipation), also known as the red elm tree, is widely used in cough drops and teas. This is because it forms a substance called mucilage when mixed with water, which coats the throat and provides relief. It is also commonly used to ease the symptoms of [laryngitis and other respiratory problems](https://www.bibliomed.org/?mno=17581), like coughing. Slippery elm contains bioflavonoids, tannins, calcium, and vitamin E, all of which provide their own unique health-boosting properties. 6. Licorice root This tea is commonly used in traditional Chinese medicine. Its flavonoid content helps boost immune health, and it has been shown to fight off various [viral and bacterial infections](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4629407/) [4](#citations). Advertisement 7. Chamomile When I'm feeling under the weather, I typically find it difficult to get good-quality sleep. But sleep is so important for healing and repairing from illness. [Sip a cup of chamomile](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/what-is-chamomile-tea) in the evening for its powerful ability to help you wind down and catch some restorative Zzz's. 8. Lemon Balm [Lemon balm tea](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/lemon-balm-uses-benefits-tea-preparations-and-more) boasts a light, sweet lemon flavor for those who like their tea on the sweet, not bitter, side. It has high vitamin C content to add to your quotient for the day and is a great [natural sleep aid](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22207903) [5](#citations). Advertisement 9. Peppermint If you are congested, [peppermint tea](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/benefits-of-peppermint-oil) is a great option. Peppermint leaves naturally contain menthol, which [clears the sinuses](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19039907) [6](#citations) and opens up your nasal passages. It can also help soothe any nausea you may be experiencing. 10. Pu-erh [Pu-erh tea](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/health-benefits-of) is made from the true tea plant, Camellia sinensis (which is where black, green, white, and oolong teas come from). Because of this, you can find Pu-erh varieties in green, black, or white tea. Pu-erh is classically known to come from the Yunnan province in China. Studies [have pointed](https://doi.org/10.1007/s00253-011-3501-2) to Pu-erh having antibacterial properties, which means it can help fight off harmful bacteria. So next time you are feeling under the weather, grab your largest mug, your coziest blanket, and curl up with one of these cold- and flu-fighting teas!
